posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Elf makes this build combo extremely slow developing and somewhat painful. However, I've tried to keep the XP penalty at a minimum.  Figure -20% XP from 15 to 22 and again 35 to end (actually a few levels -40% as well; see the leveling guide to find out when that happens).  No way around it really.

The monk/rogue combo is a natural ED bias so I built that way.  With the divine buffs, both AB and damage should be greater than typical non-preisty Dexers plus you'll get 7d6 sneaks against susceptible targets (and Crippling Strike... late in epic). 

This is a DW schedule.  I'm figuring robes w/2 kamas but you could choose any finessable weapon theoretically.  However, except for kamas, you'll lose the monk progression which pretty much defeats the reason to take that class in the first place.  There is no room for both metamagic and DW in such a feat-starved combo.  That should not come as a surprise.  However, you could bypass DW altogether, just stick with a single kama (no shield, of course) and take Extend and Empower (plus a spare pre-epic feat) which will increase the effectiveness of your buffs. 

You should have no problem reaching the AB cap with those high-magic weapons and divine buffs (need I list them all??).  That means AB 57.  If you can max Dex enhancements, that translates to another 6 AB or 63 total which will hit an AC of 53 or lower at least half of the attacks.  DW kamas with ImpTWF and Flurry will be in the neighborhood of 8APR non-hasted, no divine power... so you can add 2 more to that total when buffed with those effects.

The overall layout is:

Monk(12), Rogue(13), Cleric(15), Elf

STR: 10
DEX: 18 (26)
CON: 12
WIS: 14 (18)
INT: 14
CHA: 8

Monk12 achieves Diamond Soul. Rog13 gets that bonus feat.  They are kept equal as best they can throughout the leveling sequence for the XP pen issue..
Epic Dodge at Level 30 (3 levels later than earliest possible).

Recommended Domains: Trickery/War or Trickery/Animal   (or Plant/War, if there is access to Imp Invis scrolls.)  Naturally, without permahaste items or speed pots, Travel would be a significant alternative.

HP: 334  (figure anywhere from 40-120 more HP depending on whether Empower meta can be fit in or not)

Note: you'll need to sacrifice your only detect skill if you want to manage traps and/or locks and get some use out of that Trickery domain skill boost.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
The experience penalty would be 20%, not just 10%.
I would take Two Weapon Fighting earlier than Ambidexterity because it reduces the penalty on all attacks by 2, while Ambidexterity improves only the single (until Improved TWF) off-hand attack, albeit by 4. Then again, I wouldn't start dual-wielding until I have both of those feats. Furthermore, I would take Weapon Finesse and Weapon Focus at levels 3 and 6, waiting until level 9 to start taking dual-wielding feats, and then delay Improved Critical to level 15 or maybe even 18 to get 2 or all 3 dual-wielding feats first.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:
The experience penalty would be 20%, not just 10%.
 
It's even worse than that. There are 4 levels with 40% penalty. :(
I would take Two Weapon Fighting earlier than Ambidexterity because it reduces the penalty on all attacks by 2, while Ambidexterity improves only the single (until Improved TWF) off-hand attack, albeit by 4. Then again, I wouldn't start dual-wielding until I have both of those feats.
Good points all.
Furthermore, I would take Weapon Finesse and Weapon Focus at levels 3 and 6, waiting until level 9 to start taking dual-wielding feats, and then delay Improved Critical to level 15 or maybe even 18 to get 2 or all 3 dual-wielding feats first.
Both Finesse and WF require BAB+1 and at level 3 it is BAB 0 due to all the class stacking. That's why I stuck one of the DW feats there. TWF is a better choice. I agree.
But I disagree about delaying ImpCrit.  It is unaffected by AB (you can roll a 19 or 20 regardless of your AB).  I always get ImpCrit asap because it doubles crit opps regardless of weapon. Keen Edge scrolls further enhance the importance of early ImpCrit in any UMD build (or keen weapons for that matter).

I completely agree about how to time when it is appropriate to start DWing.  I consider ImpTWF the least useful of the three and often bypass it altogether (if feat-starved) since it adds a -5 BAB  attack (yes, for monk also) and in early levels essentially a guaranteed miss.  If the toon is having trouble hitting at all with DW, ImpTWF won't help other than 1 more chance at rolling a 20.

Bottom line in this build is that DW is a forced fit and, really, not a necessary one.  Without fighter or CoT BAB early on, everything gets delayed far beyond what it should be.  The main reason I went DW is due to monk's reliance on robes with no shield.  That empty hand could be doing something more than waving in the breeze, hence the impetus to DW. Throwing the racial curve into the mix further strangles what could have been an otherwise more conventional implementation of this particular class split.

I've revised the leveling guide to include those suggestions that seem most reasonable and leave it to the OP to decide how to custom fit it according to his environment.
